question: In patients receiving red blood cell transfusions, does leukoreduction of RBC units reduce the incidence of serious nosocomial infections compared with non-leukoreduced transfusions? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The frequency of posttransfusion fevers decreased significantly following leukoreduction (adjusted OR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.79-0.94), as did antibiotic use (adjusted OR, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.82-0.99).
content.source_2: In a propensity-matched multicenter cohort, universal leukoreduction was associated with a significant reduction in serious nosocomial infections (adjusted OR 0.72, 95% CI 0.64–0.81) relative to the pre-implementation period.
content.source_3: Following national adoption of leukoreduced red cells, mortality declined and patients experienced fewer febrile episodes with reduced antibiotic use after transfusion; however, the rate of serious hospital-acquired infections remained unchanged (adjusted OR 0.97, 95% CI 0.87–1.09).
content.source_4: An interrupted time-series across regional hospitals found that after leukoreduction, both posttransfusion fever and empiric antibiotic initiation increased (adjusted ORs 1.18 [1.06–1.31] and 1.12 [1.01–1.25], respectively), suggesting more infectious complications.
